workflow_tags: data selection, meta regression, summary statistics, feature engineering,data standardization
domain_knowledge: 1. When working with multiple studies that are original and replicated, a preprocess & joining step is needed to gather the data required for metaregression analysis. 2. Combining such study data has to account for study & author names and may need multiple heuristics for the ideal join depending on the line of inquiry. 3. An extra step may also be required to handle duplicate values & missing pairs.

datasets.name: meta-regression_joined_data_heterogeneity_in_replication_projects.csv
datasets.description: Data created by merging data.csv and RProjects.csv

raw.name: study
raw.description: Study identifier, usually names of authors from original study

raw.name: project.x
raw.description: The replication project that the study was on (Psychology or Experimental Economics)

raw.name: ro
raw.description: Effect estimate of original study on correlation scale

raw.name: rr
raw.description: Effect estimate of replication study on correlation scale

raw.name: fiso
raw.description: Effect estimate of original study transformed to Fisher-z scale

raw.name: fisr
raw.description: Effect estimate of replication study transformed to Fisher-z scale

raw.name: se_fiso
raw.description: Standard error of Fisher-z transformed effect estimate of original study

raw.name: se_fisr
raw.description: Standard error of Fisher-z transformed effect estimate of replication study

raw.name: po
raw.description: Two-sided p-value from significance test of effect estimate from original study

raw.name: pr
raw.description: Two-sided p-value from significance test of effect estimate from replication study

raw.name: po1
raw.description: One-sided p-value from significance test of effect estimate from original study (in the direction of the original effect estimate)

raw.name: pr1
raw.description: One-sided p-value from significance test of effect estimate from replication study (in the direction of the original effect estimate)

raw.name: pm_belief
raw.description: Peer belief about whether replication effect estimate will achieve statistical significance elicited through prediction market (only available for EERP and SSRP)

raw.name: no
raw.description: Sample size in original study

raw.name: nr
raw.description: Sample size in replication study

raw.name: authors.o
raw.description: Names of Original paper's authors

raw.name: pub_year
raw.description: Year of Publication of the study

raw.name: journal
raw.description: Journal in which the study was published

raw.name: discipline
raw.description: Discipline of original paper. One of the following: Social, Cognitive or Economics

raw.name: length
raw.description: Number of pages of original paper

raw.name: citations
raw.description: Number of citations of original paper

raw.name: n.r
raw.description: Sample size of replication

raw.name: power.o
raw.description: Post hoc power based on original effect size

raw.name: power.r
raw.description: Post hoc power based on replication effect size

raw.name: power_planned.r
raw.description: Planned power of the replication based on planned N and original ES

raw.name: experiment_country.o
raw.description: Country where original experiment was conducted

raw.name: experiment_country.r
raw.description: Country where replication is to be conducted

raw.name: experiment_language.o
raw.description: Language used with subjects in original experiment (English, German, Dutch, Polish, Hebrew, French, Italian, Arabic, Spanish, Korean)

raw.name: experiment_language.r
raw.description: Language to be used with subjects in replication (English, Polish, German, Dutch, Italian, Portuguese, Malay, Turkish, Czech, Arabic, Spanish)

raw.name: online.o
raw.description: If the original experiment was conducted online (1: yes, 0: no)

raw.name: online.r
raw.description: If the replication was conducted online (1: yes, 0: no)

raw.name: compensation.o
raw.description: Compensation in original experiment (credit, cash, nothing, mixed)

raw.name: compensation.r
raw.description: Compensation in replication (credit, cash, nothing, mixed)

raw.name: subjects.o
raw.description: Type of subjects used in original experiment (students, online, anyone, community)

raw.name: subjects.r
raw.description: Type of subjects used in replication (students, online, anyone, community)

raw.name: endprice
raw.description: Final market price in prediction market

raw.name: transactions
raw.description: Number of transactions in prediction market

raw.name: trading_volume
raw.description: Total volume of traded stocks in prediction market

raw.name: replicated
raw.description: Binary outcome variable; study is replicated if p <= 0.05 and effect goes in the same direction as the original

raw.name: project.y
raw.description: The replication project that the study was on (rpp: Psychology or ee: Experimental Economics)

raw.name: relative_es
raw.description: The continuous outcome variable; the standardized replication effect size to the original effect | relative effect size = (replication effect size / original effect size)

raw.name: n_authors.o
raw.description: Number of authors in original study

raw.name: n_authors.r
raw.description: Number of authors in replication

raw.name: author_citations_avg.o
raw.description: Average number of citations of authors in original study

raw.name: author_citations_max.o
raw.description: Number of citations of the author in original study with the highest citation count

raw.name: authors_male.o
raw.description: Ratio of male authors in original study

raw.name: seniority.o
raw.description: Most senior author in the original paper (Professor, Associate Professor, Assistant, Researcher, Assistant Professor)

raw.name: author_citations_avg.r
raw.description: Average number of citations of authors in replication study

raw.name: author_citations_max.r
raw.description: Number of citations of the author in original study with the highest citation count

raw.name: authors_male.r
raw.description: Ratio of male authors in replication

raw.name: seniority.r
raw.description: Most senior author in the original paper (Professor, Associate Professor, Assistant, Researcher, Assistant Professor)

raw.name: aggregated
raw.description: Aggregated column

raw.name: lab_id
raw.description: Unique id for each replication lab

raw.name: es_80power
raw.description: Standardized effect size required in replication to achieve 80% power

raw.name: same_country
raw.description: Original study and replication are in the same country

raw.name: same_language
raw.description: Original study and replication are in the same language

raw.name: same_online
raw.description: Original study and replication are both conducted online

raw.name: same_subjects
raw.description: Original study and replication use same type of subjects

raw.name: us_lab.o
raw.description: Original experiment lab in the US

raw.name: us_lab.r
raw.description: Replication experiment lab in the US

queries.question: In which domain do the majority of authors tend to be male for both original and replication studies?
What is the ratio of male authors in replication studies in Experimental Economics?
